Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Dewi Harjanto of Boston University to conduct a research project, entitled "Using a mechanically-sensitive polymer to study cell-generated forces," during the summer of 2012 at Hanyang University in Seoul, Korea. The host scientist is Professor Jong-Man Kim.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is in the use of the mechanically-sensitive polymer, polydiacetylene (PDA), in a potentially very powerful, novel application. By seeding live cells in RGD-functionalized 3D PDA scaffolds, researchers are attempting to directly observe and quantify traction force generation by cells in 3D based on color changes in the polymer. This highly interdisciplinary work combines chemical engineering and biology and promises to result in the development of a novel quantitative platform to study cell-matrix mechanics.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this work, entitled “Using a mechanically-sensitive polymer to study cell-generated forces” we aimed to create a novel material that combined the cell recognition peptide sequence RGD with the mechanically-sensitive polymer, polydiacetylene (PDA) for use in studying and measuring traction forces exerted by a cell against its matrix. PDA is a popular material for sensing applications since it changes color upon stimulation. By creating a matrix made out of this RGD-PDA material, one could feasibly directly observe and quantify forces generated by seeded cells by looking at color changes in the polymer in three dimensions. This is in contrast to current traction force microscopy techniques, which are inherently limited to providing measurements in two dimensions. In order to achieve this aim, we tested out different concentrations of RGD in the RGD-PDA conjugated material to determine which bound cells the best. We also demonstrated that cells were indeed capable of binding to the RGD-functionalized PDA matrix, and that cell binding was visible by fluorescence microscopy. In doing this work, we also developed a new cell adhesion assay designed to measure the adhesiveness of polymers in liposome form in contrast to polymers that have been prepared in film form. This research is highly interdisciplinary, combining chemical engineering and biology to develop a potentially very powerful new tool for studying cell-matrix interactions.
